div.head: NPpro=Npr
div.p: complex pronoun preceding and in apposition with a proper name.

div.head: padV.postN{SUBJ}:adS
div.p: particle preceding and modifying a verbal expression, that whole expression being in construction with a preceding nominal subject, this whole phrase in turn preceding and modifying a sentence.

div.head: npost=N
div.p: An n preceded by an N that is in apposition with it.

div.head: padV.adS
div.p: particle preceding and modifying a verbal expression, and that whole phrase preceding and modifying a sentence.

div.head: vt+V[0]{PASS}.adN
div.p: transitive verb followed by a passive verbal construction with an obligatorily omitted syntactically predictable subject, this whole construction preceding and modifying a nominal expression.

div.head: vttoN1.+N2:adV
div.p: ditransitive verb with two nominal obejcts, this whole phrase preceding and modifying a main verbal expression

div.head: vt[oN.]+V[0]{PASS}:adN
div.p: transtive verb with a lexically determinate omitted object, that whole construction followed by and in construction with a passive verbal expression with a lexically determinate omitted subject, the whole construction so far described modifying and being followed by a nominal expression

div.head: vt(oN1.)+prep+N2
div.p: transitive verb with a contextually determinate object, that construction being followed by a prepositional phrase.

div.head: vt0.+prep+N:adV
div.p: subjectless transitive verb followed by its object introduced by a preposition, and this whole phrase preceding and modifying a main verb phrase (e.g. da4o 到 "until" as in 民到于今受其賜 "and the people down to present times enjoy the benefits thereof")

note.p: The V may be construed as a minor sentence.

div.head: VPi+N{PLACE}
div.p: intransitive complex verbal expression followed by and in construction with a place noun.

div.head: padV{NEG}
div.p: particle preceding and modifying a negative verb.

div.head: nnm
div.p: nominal mass binome, the constituents of which have no independent meaning.

div.head: vtt+V:post.vtoN
div.p: ditransitive verb with a verbal object, that phrase being in construction with a preceding transitive (co)verb with its object (which provides one of the objects of the ditransitive verb)

div.head: n[adN]
div.p: Exocentric expression consisting of a monosyllabic noun modifying a lexically determinate omitted nominal expression.

div.head: PP[adN.]adS
div.p: Complex particle modifying a lexically determinate N, that whole expression modifying a sentence S.

div.head: nab.t:c
div.p: transitive abstract count noun

note.p: The pheonomena of transitivity of abstract nouns is underexplored as yet in TLS. Many more cases need to be registered and subclassified.

div.head: npostadS
div.p: noun following after and modifying a sentence.

div.head: vt(oN1.)+Vt+N2
div.p: transitive verb with an omitted contextually determinate object, this construction preceding a construction constisting of a transitive verbal expression followed by a nominal expression.

div.head: p[adV]
div.p: particle modifying a lexically determinate omitted verbal expression.

note.p: I.e. an exocentric verbal construction, compare "I did not" which is also exocentric.

div.head: vadV
div.p: deverbal word preceding and modifying a verbal expression, traditionally: a deverbal adverb in preverbal position

note.p: The distinction between the categories vadV, nadV, and padV is problematic whenever it is unclear from which function it is most natural to derive the adverbial use in question.

The distinction with the presentential vadS must remain uncertain whenever it is unclear whether what follows is simply a verbal expression or must be taken as a verbal sentence with an implicit understood subject.

div.head: VPi.red
div.p: reduplicated intransitive complex verbal

bibl.title: 漢語重言詞詞典 Hanyu chongwenci cidian

div.head: VPi(0)
div.p: complex verbal expression with a contextually determinate idiomatically omitted subject

div.head: VPt+prep+N.adV
div.p: transitive complex verb followed by a preposition and the object, this whole phrase preceding and modifying a verbal expression.

div.head: vadNab{ACT}
div.p: verb preceding and modifying an abstract action nominal

note.p: One might obviously have classified this as a straighforward vadN, but it seems worth looking out for adjectives that modify action nominalisations.

div.head: vtt+N1{PIVOT}.+N2{PRED}
div.p: ditransitive (causative) verb followed by pivotal object N1 (who is caused to vtt) the object N2

note.p: This is an extraordinary syntactic frame, and time must show whether it is unique. The special syntactic case arises from the fact that the causativeness in the verb leads to a special assignment of roles to the two object nouns. I suppose one might also impose a meaning like "impose on N1's shoulders the object N2, in which case we should simply have a plain vtt+N1.+N2.

div.head: nab.post-N
div.p: abstract noun following after and modified by a nominal expression

div.head: NPpost-N.adS
div.p: NP preceded and modified by a nominal expression, that whole expression preceding and modifying a sentence.

div.head: VPttoN1.+N2
div.p: ditransitive complex verb in construction followed by its two objects, both irreplacable by the object pronoun zhi1 之 .

div.head: vt[0]{NEG}(+V[0])
div.p: transitive negation verb with an invariant omitted subject and with a contextually determinate omitted verbal object which has an omitted syntactically predictable invariant subject.

div.head: vtoS.adV{PRED}:postN{SUBJ}
div.p: transitive verb with a sentential object, this construction preceding and modifying a verbal predicate, that whole construction being preceded by the nominal subject

div.head: npro0(.adN)
div.p: non-referential pronoun modifying an omitted nominal head of the construction.

note.p: This is a so-called "exocentric" use of an impersonal pronoun.
The "0" after pronouns refers to non-referential pronouns in the sense that the pronouns in questions do not invite one to identify any item, set, or person.

div.head: vt(+prep+N)
div.p: transitive verb with a contextually determinate omitted prepositional phrase

div.head: vi+HU1
div.p: intransitive verb followed by the intensitive descriptive particle hu 乎

note.p: I keep this absurdly formulated category as a reminder that one will want to collect intransitive verbs which are followed by 乎 .

div.head: npr{2}
div.p: Proper name that is counted.

div.head: ntpost-N
div.p: transitive noun, i.e. a noun which is semantically transitive on the one hand, and for which the semantic object is expressed explicitly

note.p: The notion that not only abstract nouns but also concrete nouns can be transitive is current from many studies in the valency of words. MEL'CUK 1984-1999 presents in commendable detail many relevant cases in what he calles the "regime" of a noun. The notion of a ruler is transitive because a ruler is only a ruler to the extent that he is a ruler of a realm. A protector is only a protector to the extent that there is something which he protects. A murderer is only a murderer to the extent that there is someone he has killed. All agent nominalisations of transitive verbs retain the transitivity of the verb from which they derive in this abstract sense. Even the notion of a "wife" differs from that of a woman that the former is relational and technically speaking transitive whereas the latter is not. Thus the class of transitive nouns that are modified by other nouns that precede them in this specific "transitive" way is considerable. A large number of what are now still simply nouns in TLS will have to be reclassified as ntpost-N.

div.head: vt+npro.adN
div.p: transitive verb preceding its pronominal object, this whole phrase modifying a main nominal

note.p: One wonders if one should not create one larger category vt+N.adN.

div.head: vtoN.adVt
div.p: transitive verb with its nominal object preceding and modifying a transitive verbal (of which it marks the object)

div.head: NPadV
div.p: complex nominal preceding and modifying a verbal

div.head: NP[post=npro1.]postVt
div.p: NP preceded and modified by a lexically determinate understood first person pronoun, that whole expression

div.head: padN1(PRED).postN2{SUBJ}
div.p: particle preceding and modifying a (predicative) nominal, this whose phrase being in construction with a preceding (subject) nominal

note.p: This category captures the fact that the predicate may be nominal, or - if one prefers - a classificatory denominal verb.

div.head: npro=Npr
div.p: pronoun followed by and in apposition with a proper name.

note.p: Apposition, marked as "++" is as between "I" and "George W. Bush" in the phrase "I, George W. Bush".

div.head: VPttoN.+S
div.p: ditransitive complex verbal followed by a nominal object, that phrase being followed by a sentential object.

div.head: VPt+.VtoS
div.p: complex transitive verb followed by its object in the form of a transitive verbal expression with its sentential object.

div.head: npro.adV:adS
div.p: pronoun preceding and modifying (e.g. nominalising or subordinating) a verbal expression, that whole phrase preceding and modifying a sentence.

div.head: vtoN.+yi3+V
div.p: transitive verb with its nominal object, that phrase being followed by 以／已 and a verb (mostly 來 )

div.head: vadN{PRED}
div.p: verb preceding and modifying a nominal predicate

div.head: NP{n1-n2}
div.p: complex nominal; construction type: nominal followed by a suffix "npostadN" which comes out as "-N2" in this formula
[THE BRACKET NEEDS TO BE TRANSFERRED TO THE FIELD "CONSTRUCTION TYPE"]

note.p: Nominal suffixation in classical Chinese is relatively rare, the only productive suffix being 子 . And in a case like 豎子 the problem whether 子 is or is not a suffix remains undecidable. Both views can be supported by arguments, and very importantly: the question which of these analyses is correct is alien to Chinese commentatorial thinking.

div.head: nad.VtoN
div.p: adnominal adverb preceding and modifying a transitive verb with an explicit nominal object

note.p: Note that the reference of the initial n here often is to the object (as in the English "nourish your guest like your own child") but can in principle also refer to the subject ("experience things like a child").

div.head: vtoN.adS
div.p: transitive verb with nominal object, that whole phrase preceding and modifying a sentence

div.head: NP[post=npro2.]postVt
div.p: noun phrase in apposition with an omitted preceding second person pronoun, this whole construction serving as an object for a preceding transitive verb.

div.head: npro+Vt(oN)
div.p: pronoun followed by a transitive verbal expression with a contextually determinate unexpressed object

div.head: vttoN:+.vt+Nab{S}
div.p: ditransitive verb followed by its indirect object that whole construction being followed by a transitive verb with its abstract nominal object.

note.p: This is certainly an odd category to introduce. The nominalisation of the S being unmarked. Still, the category may serve as a reminder for a construction that needs a proper analysis.

div.head: vadV{NUM}.adN
div.p: adverb, preceding and modifying a verb which is a numeral; the whole phrase preceding and modifying a nominal.

div.head: ncc(post-npro.)+N
div.p: counted noun modified by a omitted contextually determinate pronoun, that whole expression being followed by and in construction with a nominal expression.

div.head: vpostadN
div.p: verb modifying a preceding noun.

div.head: vttoN.+VtoS
div.p: ditransitive verb followed by its nominal object, this phrase followed by a transitive verb with its sentential object.

div.head: VPtt(oN1.)(+N2)
div.p: ditransitive verbal phrase with to contextually determinate omitted objects

div.head: {vi-...}
div.p: {intransitive verbal constituent modified by what follows it}

div.head: VPt[0]+V[0]
div.p: complex verbal with a lexically determinate idiomatically omitted subject and a verbal object the subject of which is lexically determinate on the basis of the main VP.

div.head: p{S}
div.p: particle (usually exclamatory particle) which functions as independent sentence.

div.head: VPi[0]
div.p: comples verbal with a lexically determinate idiomatically omitted subject

div.head: npro{OBJ}+Vt.adVt
div.p: object pronoun preceding a transitive verb, that whole construction preceding and modifying a transitive verbal expression.

div.head: vpost-V{NUM}.postadV
div.p: verb modified by a preceding number verb, this whole construction modifying a preceding verbal expression

div.head: vttoN.+V[0]
div.p: ditranstive verb with a nominal object, this construction preceding and in construction with a verbal expression

note.p: This category assembles structurally similar verbs all of which are similarly hard to analyse. The question how exactly an analysis of pivotal constructions should proceed remains highly sensitive and deserves much more discussion.

However, the words that will need to be discussed in this connection are assembled in this category. There are many instances where the role of TLS can only be to identify examples relevant to problem areas for analysis and examples of probematic "isopmorphic" phenomena, rather than solving the problems raised by these phenomena. The identification of structurally similar sets is in itself only a first step. But it is a necessary step. Close analysis will probably show that much of what is called pivotal here is not really pivotal.

div.head: vt:+N.+SUO3+Vt
div.p: transitive verb followed by a construction consisting of a noun followed by 所 which is in turn followed by a transitive verbal expression.

note.p: NOTE
The constituent structure here is stimulatingly confusing and needs detailed argumentation.

div.head: nt[post-N]
div.p: relational noun modified by an omitted lexically determinate nominal expression.

div.head: vadV+V
div.p: deverbal adverb modifying a verb, followed by a verbal expression

div.head: vt{NEG}+.Vt1(+Vt2)
div.p: transitive negation verb with a transitive verbal object which in turn has a transitive verbal object

div.head: NPpostadV
div.p: complex nominal modifying a preceding verbal

note.p: Postposed adverbials are not rare, and this group could be greatly expanded if one allowed non-lexicalised phrases.

div.head: vttoN(.+V[0])
div.p: ditransitive verb with its object, this phrase preceding and being in construction with a contextually determinate omitted verbal expression

note.p: The existence of this category is theoretically important as subsidiary evidence on the non-eliptic form of the same construction.

div.head: vtoS.adV
div.p: transitive verb with a sentential object, this whole phrase preceding and modifying a verbal expression

note.p: One might be tempted to take the S to be a case of unmarked sentence nominalisation. Many cases of this phenomenon need to be compared before one can make an informed decision on this possibility. And even if one decides that this is ultimately how one wishes to take these cases, it will be interesting to have such cases as a significant sub-category of vt+N.adV.

div.head: npost-N.+Npr
div.p: transitive noun preceded and modified by a nominal expression, this whole phrase followed by and in construction with a proper name

div.head: vadS1.post-S2
div.p: a verb (or: deverbal particle) preceding and modifying a sentence, that whole phrase being in construction with a preceding sentence

note.p: See the category padS1.postS2 which is closely related to this one. Deverbals do emerge in our system as "v", their grammaticalisation is indicated by their syntactic embedding, these "v" being either "ad" or "post" something else.

div.head: vtoNab
div.p: transitive verb with an abstract nominal as an object

div.head: vtoS.post-V
div.p: transitive verb with a sentential object that whole construction folling after and being modified by a verbal expression.

div.head: vt(postN1[EGO].)postN2:+V{PRED}
div.p: transitive verb with an understood first person subject, preceded by a noun, and this whole construction being followed by a verbal predicative expression.

note.p: An extraordinary category, parenthetic expressions being so rare in classical Chinese.

div.head: vttoN1.+N2{PRED}
div.p: ditransitive verb followed by its direct object, this construction being followed by a predicative nominal expression.

div.head: vtt[0]oN1.+N2
div.p: ditransitive verb with an invariant predictable idiomatically omitted subject, followed by its direct object N1, this whole construction being followed by the indirect object N2.

div.head: VPt0+V(0)
div.p: verb phrase with a lexically predictable omitted subject followed by a verbal object with a syntactically predictable omitted subject

div.head: npro.post-N:+S
div.p: pronoun preceded and modified by a nominal expression, that whole phrase being followed by a sentence

div.head: {VP-...}
div.p: {complex verbal constituent modified by what comes after it}

div.head: VPt[0]+N
div.p: transitive verb phrase with contextually determinate obligatorily omitted subject

note.p: This category raises a host of problems. The subject who does the comparing can definitely never be explicit. 諸 stands for something like 之於 and would appear to make this into a VPt0+prep+N, although one suspects a more appropriate way of analysing the idiom could be to take 譬 as vtt0+N1.+prep+N2 and to refuse to treat this as a compound at all. But for lexicographic purposes we do want to record this compound as an important idiom one has to learn.

div.head: vt+Vt.oS
div.p: a transitive verb preceding and in construction with another transitive verb, and that phrase followed by an object sentence.

div.head: NPab.pr
div.p: personified complex abstraction

note.p: Note that personification always remains a matter of degree.

div.head: padV.postnpro{Q}
div.p: particle preceding and in construction with a verbal expression, that phrase being in construction with a preceding question pronoun

div.head: vt0(+N)
div.p: subjectless transitive verb with a contextually determinate omitted object.

div.head: ppostadV
div.p: a particle in construction with (and modifying) a preceding verbal expression

div.head: VPt0oN{SUBJ}
div.p: grammatically subjectless transitive verbal expression followed by a nominal which one is tempted to take as the logical subject.

note.p: This category is profoundly problematic, and there is even serious doubt that it is homogeneous.

div.head: VPtoS1.adS2
div.p: transitive complex verbal expression with its sentential object, this construction modifying another sentence that follows.

div.head: vi-V
div.p: intransitive verb preceding and modified by a verbal expression.
Contrast vt(+N.)-V 往 "go there to V".

div.head: {ppostN...}
div.p: {pronoun following after and in construction with a nominal constituent}

div.head: vt0+Nab{S1}.adS2
div.p: logically subjectless (grammaticalised) verb with its nominalised-sentence object, that whole construction preceding and modifying a second sentence.

div.head: padS.postN{TOP}
div.p: adsentential particle following after the nominal topic.

div.head: vt[0]oN.adV
div.p: transitive verb with a lexically determinate omitted subject, followed by its object, that whole construction preceding and modifying a verbal expression.

div.head: vpostadV1.adV2
div.p: a verb following after and modifying a verbal expression, and that whole construction preceding and modifying another verbal expression

div.head: VPtt[oN1.]+N2
div.p: verbal expression with an omitted lexically determinate reflexive direct object and followed by a nominal complement

div.head: vttoN1[.+prep+N2]
div.p: ditransitive verb followed by its direct object, this construction followed by a lexically determinate omitted second nominal expression.

div.head: npro.post-V
div.p: pronoun following after and being modified by a verb.

div.head: vtpostadVt1.+Vt2
div.p: transitive verb postmodifying a transitive verbal expression, this construction preceding and in construction with another transitive verb.

div.head: vad.VtoN
div.p: a verb which precedes and modifies a transitive verb with its object

note.p: These words have this in common that they modify the verb phrase they precede by quantifying into the object. In principle, we have a grammatical relation between non-contiguous elements here.
Many of the words in this category are specialised on object quantification, others - like 皆 - are only occasionally found in this function and normally quantify the subject.

div.head: vadNab
div.p: verb preceding and modifying an abstract noun.

div.head: VPi(0)postN{PRED}
div.p: subjectless complex verbal expression with an obligatorily omitted contextually determinate subject, in construction with a preceding predicate nominal

div.head: VPt[oN]
div.p: transitive complex verbal expression with a lexically determined or predictable omitted object.

note.p: For example in the English "he drinks" we have a verb of which the object is understood lexically to be "alcohol". In "he is eating" the object that is lexically understood is "some kind of food". We must try identify the Chinese VPs that work like this and try to distinguish them carefully from intransitive verbs.

div.head: vt[0]+V[0]
div.p: subjectless transitive verb with a verbal object of which the subject is lexically predictable and omitted (e.g. bi4 必 "it is imperative to V)

note.p: The subjectlessness of these vt can be controversial. For example if a generic subject like "one" is always unexpressed, or expressed by zero, does this count as an example of subjectlessness? If it does, why do we not count as subjectless the many cases where ordinary verbs have generic subjects of this sort? I am not sure that one will be able to sort this out very satisfactorily.

div.head: PP{DISCONT}adS
div.p: discontinuous particle phrase preceding and modifying a sentence.

note.p: Our way of handling discontinuous constructions has not so far been properly systematised. 待考

div.head: vt(oN1)ad.Vt+N2
div.p: transitive verb with an omitted contextually determinate object, this construction preceding and modifying a construction constisting of a transitive verbal expression followed by a nominal expression.

div.head: {VPpost...}
div.p: {complex verbal expression which is in construction with a preceding expression of any kind}

div.head: n[post-N]
div.p: noun with an understood lexically determinate omitted nominal expression which modifies it.

div.head: ppostadN.adV
div.p: particle modifying a preceding nominal expression, and that whole construction preceding and modifying a verbal expression.

div.head: VPpostV
div.p: complex verbal expression following after and in construction with a verbal expression

div.head: {vt{COP}...}
div.p: {transitive verbal constituent which serves as a copula-like verb}

div.head: NPpostVt
div.p: complex nominal expression following after and serving as object of a transitive verbal expression

note.p: We do not normally note object-occurrence of words, but the cases of words with the semantic feature "pro" are exceptions.

div.head: vtt(oN{PIVOT}.)+N{PRED}
div.p: ditransitive verb with contextually determinate omitted pivotal object, preceding and in construction with a predicative nominal expression

note.p: Whether the N here really should be taken as a PIVOT is controversial, and in the end probably wrong. But by taking it in this way, we are able to subclassify the constructions possible in a convenient way.

div.head: vt(+N.)adV1:postV2
div.p: subjectless transitive verb with omitted object modifying a main verb V1, the whole phrase being in construction with a preceding verbal expression V2

div.head: vtoN1.adN2
div.p: transitive verb with its nominal object, this whole construction preceding and modifying a nominal expression.

div.head: vt+prep+N.adVtoS
div.p: transitive verb with its prepositional object, that phrase preceding and modifying a transitive verb with its sentential object

note.p: Maybe one should simplify the structural description of this to vt+prep+N.adV, but the important fact remains that the form of that final V is always that of Vt+S.

div.head: padS1.postS2
div.p: particle preceding and modifying a sentence, this phrase being in construction with another preceding sentence.

div.head: vt+V1.postadV2
div.p: translitive verb followed by its verbal object, this phrase modifying a verbal expression.

div.head: vtoN1:ad.VtoN2
div.p: transitive verb with its nominal object, this phrase modifying a transitive verb with its nominal object

note.p: The internal structure of this special idiomatic phrase is far from uncontroversial. Its existence needs to be seen in connection with whatever one chooses to say in the end about 命曰 .

div.head: npro.post-NPab[S1]:adS2
div.p: pronoun preceded and modified by a nominalised sentence, this construction preceding and modifying another (unnominalised) sentence

div.head: nab.post-V
div.p: abstract noun modified by a preceding verbal expression.

note.p: It is an interesting question why one should not be able to take these expressions to be nab.post-Nab. In posing this structure, is one just imposing English structural sensibilities on the Chinese? What is going on in the analysis of constructions of this sort?

div.head: ppostadN.adS
div.p: particle which follows and modifies a nominal, this whole phrase preceding and modifying a sentence

note.p: One might simply take this as a topic marker, and one could have created a more explicit category ppostN{TOP}.adS

div.head: VPt+Nab.adV
div.p: transitive complex verbal with an abstract nominal object, this phrase preceding and modifying a main verbal

div.head: vpostadV
div.p: verb that modifies a preceding verbal expression

div.head: vtt+prep+N1.oN2
div.p: ditransitive verb with its prepositional object followed by another nominal object

div.head: VPt(oS)
div.p: complex verbal with an omitted contextually determinate sentential object

div.head: VPpostN.adS
div.p: complex verbal expression in construction with a preceding nominal, this whole phrase preceding and modifying a sentence.

div.head: VPi0adV
div.p: subjectless complex verb phrase preceding and modifying a main verbal expression.

div.head: vt2
div.p: transitive verb with two subjects

note.p: See also vt2+prep+N. Compare the subjectless v0 as well as VPi2 for the form of this.

div.head: NP+V
div.p: NP in construction with a V which it precedes.
complex noun phrase in construction with and preceding a verbal expression.

div.head: vi(0).postS
div.p: verb with obligatorily omitted subject preceded by a sentence.

div.head: NPpost-N{PLACE}
div.p: complex nominal expression modified by a preceding place nominal.

div.head: vt+V/N
div.p: transitive verb followed by an expression that may be interpreted as nominal or verbal.

div.head: npro1+Vt.postN1
div.p: pronoun preceding a transitive verb, this phrase in construction with a preceding nominal that is coreferential with the pronoun

note.p: Tentatively "superscript" numbers are used to index coreference.

One might object that the coreference indicated by the index "1" here conflates syntactic and semantic features. In principle, one could banish such coreference indicators to the semantic categories field, but there is no urgent need to do this.

div.head: npropostN1.adN2
div.p: pronoun in construction with a precding a nominal expression N1, that whole construction preceding and modifying another noun N2

div.head: vt+prep+NPab{ACT}
div.p: transitive verb followed by an abstract action nominal object introduced by a preposition

div.head: npro.postadV1:adV2
div.p: pronoun modifying a preceding verbal expression, this whole phrase preceding and modifying a verb

note.p: ？？？待考

div.head: vtoN.+V
div.p: transitive verb with its object preceding and in construction with a verbal expression

div.head: nab.pr
div.p: personified abstraction

note.p: Note that personification always remains a matter of degree.

div.head: NP{PRED}
div.p: predicative complex nominal expression.

div.head: NPab
div.p: Complex abstract nominal expression.

note.p: Criteria one can try to use to determine whether a given noun is abstract:
1. cannot be counted with classifiers and are counted - if at all - not by physical items (see nab.c "counted abstract nouns")
2. cannot be quantified by universal, existential or graded quantifiers
3. cannot be specified with respect to amounts of any concrete stuff
4. the object designated by the n cannot be said to move in space
Criteria for some basic related subclassifications of nouns
Nouns that can be counted and quantified by items or concrete things are called count nouns nc.

Nouns that cannot be counted or quantified by concrete items but can be quantified by amounts or kinds rather than items are regarded as mass nouns and these are called nm. When nm are preceded by a demonstrative pronoun, the interpretation is "this kind of nm".

The identification and the semantic subclassification of abstract nouns poses insurmountable problems because abstraction clearly is a matter of degrees on the one hand, and abstraction is a heterogeneous phenomenon. The vague and necessarily overlapping semantic subcategories introduced so far are no more than a first aid towards a resolution of these severe and unresolved analytical problems. Perhaps one should have opted for no subcategorisation at all, but we have decided to make a preliminary attempt to sort the material into major groups, even at the risk of having to make many arbitrary decisions in this process of preliminary sorting. It is obvious that this general category requires detailed subclassification.

bibl.title: Abstraction in Classical Chinese Grammar and Thought

div.head: NPab.post-Npr
div.p: abstract NP being preceded and modified by a proper name nominal.

div.head: NP(post-Npr)
div.p: NP(post-N) where the N is a proper name.
a complex nominal being preceded and modified by an omitted and contextually determinate proper name.

div.head: vt0oNPab{S}.adS
div.p: subjectless transitive verb followed by a nominalised-sentence-object, this phrase modifying a sentence
( 及其飲酒也， ...)

div.head: padS1.post-S2
div.p: a particle preceding and modifying a verbal expression (typically a minor sentence), this construction as a whole following after and being in modified by another sentence S.

note.p: Here as often the categories V and S are hard to distinguish in practice. The V is often a minor sentence S.

div.head: vpostadV.adN
div.p: verb in construction with a preceding verb, this whole phrase preceding and modifying a nominal expression

div.head: vi(0)post-.VtoN
div.p: intransitive verb with an omitted contextually determinate subject following after and being in construction with a transitive verbal expression followed by its object.

div.head: vt0+S
div.p: intransitive subjectless verb followed by and in construction with a sentence.

div.head: nab.adN
div.p: abstract noun preceding and modifying a nominal expression

note.p: It will be found that a considerable number of what remains nadN in the present TLS should perhaps be recategorised as nab.adN, as Christoph Anderl has done in this category for a few words. But this will involve a major readjustment of the categorial system.

div.head: nab.t:+prep+N
div.p: transitive abstract nominal followed by a preposition with its object

note.p: As often in English, the transitivity of the transitive-verb source of deverbal nab does occasionally carry over into nominal uses. Compare the English "His question about X", "His question to N".

div.head: vt+V[0]
div.p: transitive verb with a verbal object (the subject of both verbs being lexically determinate as being the same as that of the main verb)

note.p: 1. The distinction between a verbal and a sentential (minor sentence) object is sometimes difficult to make.

2. One probably needs to divide this class into those cases where the two verbs have the same subject and those where they do not. But it seems to me that this is properly done in the semantic category assigned, the default category being the one where the subject is the same for both verbs.

3. Whether what follows a vt+V is to be taken as a V or as an action-nominalisation (nab - act) can be a puzzling question. For example, in 輕死 "make light of death" it is not very clear exactly how one would argue that 死 should be declared verbal or action-nominalised. There is also always the profoundly puzzling problem whether a subject of 死 is understood or not.

4. It is important to realise that it always remains relevant to ask what the subject is of the verbal object. One only understands the verbal object V when one recognises its logical subject to be the same as that of the main verb. However, this subject cannot be explicit. Contrast the common syntactic category vt(+N[PIVOT].)+V which exhibits the same surface structure but has quite different semantics.

div.head: vt0oNPab{S}.postadS
div.p: subjectless transitive verb with its nominalised sentence object, modifying a preceding sentence
臣為丞相治民，
三十餘年矣。
逮秦地之陝隘。

div.head: padN.postYI1QIE4
div.p: particle precding and modifying a nominal expression, this whole phrase being modified by a preceding 一切 .

div.head: vadV{NUM}.adZHE3
div.p: verb preceding and modifying a number verb, that phrase preceding and modifying 者〔

div.head: vtoN1(.postN2):adV
div.p: transitive verb with contextually determinate subject, this whole phrase modifying a V.

note.p: This would seem to be a superfluous category but I must make sure that there is nothing interesting here before I cut it out.

div.head: padV{PRED}.postN{SUBJ}.post-S
div.p: particle preceding verbal predicate, this construction following after a nominal subject, that whole construction following after and being modified by a sentence.

div.head: padV.postN{SUBJ}:postS
div.p: particle preceding and modifying a verbal expression, this phrase following after and in construction with a nominal subject, that whole phrase following after and in construction with a preceding S

div.head: NPadNab{ACT}
div.p: complex nominal preceding and modifying an abstract action nominal.

note.p: This is an experimental category.
One might simply have subsumed this under NPadN, but it will be interested to see how many cases there are of such NPs being lexicalised as modifying an action abstraction.

div.head: vttoN1(.+N2)
div.p: ditransitive verb with a nominal direct object and a second contextually determinate omitted nominal object.

div.head: vt(+N{PIVOT}.)+V
div.p: transitive verb with a contextually determinate omitted pivot, that transitive verb being followed by a verbal expression (which is construed as the predicate in the pivot-sentence.

div.head: vt+Nm
div.p: transitive verb followed by and in construction with a mass-nominal expression.

div.head: vt0oN{SUBJ}.postN{TOP}
div.p: subjectless transitive verb followed by its object which functions as the logical subject, this whole construction being preceded by a nominal expression that functions as a topic to the verbal expression it precedes.

div.head: v(adN)
div.p: verb modifying an implicit contextually determinate nominal expression

div.head: vt[0]{NEG}+.Vt[0](+V)
div.p: Negative verb with a lexically determinate omitted subject prededing and in construction with a transitive verbal construction of which the verbal complement is omitted and contextually determinate.

div.head: nadV.adS
div.p: noun preceding and modifying a verbal expression, and that whole expression in turn preceding and modifying a sentence

div.head: nab.t
div.p: transitive abstract noun, i.e. an abstract, typically deverbal, noun the concept of which involves an action directed at an object

note.p: Action nouns are often semantically as transitive as the verbs they derive from. The transitive verb "to murder Caesar" seems exactly as transitive as the corresponding noun "the murder of Caesar". (For "Caesar's murderer" see the category of transitive agent nouns "nt - ag".
Note that "murder" can be considered as such, without any focus on who gets murdered. But even in that case, murder remains something that is construed as murder of someone.

This is a preliminary collection of some nouns that would need to be considered in connection with transitivity of abstract nouns. One is tempted to subsume them under the straightforward nab category, but it seems useful to keep them separate for a while as a point of departure for a proper study of the phenomeon of transitivity in nouns.

div.head: npro.adV
div.p: pronoun preceding and modifying a verbal expression; traditionally: de-pronominal adverb

note.p: In a traditionalist manner these words are taken as pronouns. The objective syntactic criteria for their being pronouns in this context remain unclear.
Contrast npro+V, which has all the pronouns which function as subject.

div.head: vi-V{SUFF}
div.p: verb followed and modified by a verbal suffix

note.p: There is a large set of words that fit into this category. One is in doubt whether this category should not really be "vi-V". By calling it "v-V" for the time being we (perhaps lamely) suggest that the word really enters into a one-word combination with the suffix. See the monograph by M. Kuenstler (Les suffixes...). This group still has to be implemented.

div.head: npost-.N+ZHI
div.p: noun preceded and modified by a phrase consisting of a nominal expression followed by 之 .

div.head: npro+Vt:adN
div.p: a pronoun in construction with and preceding a transitive verb, this phrase in turn prededing and modifying a nominal expression

div.head: vtt{PASS}+prep+N{SUBJ}.+V
div.p: ditransitive (passive) verb preceding and in construction with a prepositional phrase (the nominal object of this functioning as logical subject of the ditransitive verb), this whole phrase preceding and being in construction with a following verb

note.p: The paraphrase of this is unreadable, whereas the formula is clear enough as soon as one has grasped the basic syntax of such formulae.

div.head: NP[post=npro1.]adN
div.p: NP preceded and modified by a lexically determinate understood first person pronoun, that whole expression preceding and modifying a nominal expression.

div.head: vt0+V.adS
div.p: subjectless transitive verb with a verbal object, this prase preding and modifying a sentence (e.g. we4i 為 as in 為悅其言，因任其身 "Because they feel pleased with someone's use of words they go on to employ the person for that reason." )

note.p: There is no subject for 為 whereas the subject is merely omitted and understood in the case of 悅 .

This is another case where the category V in the object really refers to a minor SENTENCE. Thus perhaps this category should be reclassified as vt0+S1.adS2. One might even consider the possibility of taking the V to be really an unmarked nominalisation. Thus this category deserves further study.

div.head: NP[post-N.][post=npro1]
div.p: NP[post-N] in apposition with a lexically determinate omitted first pronoun npro1.

div.head: vttoN.-vtoNab{S}
div.p: ditransitive verb with a nominal object, this phrase preceding and being modified by a (co)verb with its nominalised sentence object

note.p: The ditransitive verb has only one object and the second object is introduced by a coverbal phrase. It is not a trivial task to bring this semantico-syntactic fact out elegantly in our categorial system, but it remains an important observation that coverbal expressions before or after a verb may on the one side specify an object of that verb, and may on the other hand have completely independent functions that have nothing to do with the valency of the verb.

div.head: nadN.adV
div.p: noun preceding and modifying a nominal expression, that whole expression preceding and modifying a verbal expression

note.p: Compare the common and similar but not idential vadN.adV as in 白日 "in broad daylight".

div.head: PPadV.post-S
div.p: disyllabic particle preceding and modifying a verbal expression, that phrase following and being modified by sentence

div.head: VPpostN
div.p: complex verbal(?) phrase in construction with a preceding nominal expression

div.head: NPpost-Npr
div.p: complex nominal expression typically modified by preceding proper name.

div.head: NPab{Nab1&Nab2}
div.p: abstract complex noun; construction type: a conjunction of two abstract nominals
[THE BRACKET NEEDS TO BE TRANSFERRED TO THE FIELD "CONSTRUCTION TYPE"]

note.p: Through this category I am trying to capture the difference between antonym compounds like 大小 indicating a dimension and additive compounds like 短長 "strong points and weak points". Probably, a fair number of what have been preliminarily classified as [N1antN2] should be considered for reclassification as [N1&N2]. Compare [Nab1antNab2] This has to be sorted out. 待考

div.head: vtoN1.adN2
div.p: transitive verb with its nominal object N1, this phrase preceding and modifying another nominal expression N

note.p: A transitive verb with its object modifying a noun is a construction that comes close to an unmarked relative clause. The important observation is that while this construction is possible in classical Chinese it is certainly not highly developed in pre-Buddhist times.

div.head: vtoN1.-v{NUM}adN2:adS
div.p: transitive (co)verb with nominal time object, preceding and modified by a quantified nominal expression, this whole phrase preceding and modifying a sentence

note.p: This is a puzzling marginal syntactic category of which there should also be antonymic examples such as 後 . But I have not yet been able to register any of these.

div.head: NPm.adN
div.p: complex mass nominal preceding and modifying a nominal.

note.p: Given the large number of nmadN, it is interesting how comparatively rare the NPmadN have so far turned out to be. There must be many more.

div.head: p+N1.post-N2
div.p: particle preceding a nominal (expressing a place or a time), that phrase being in construction with a preceding second nominal

note.p: N1 has to refer to a location in concrete or abstract space or in time in this construction. Interestingly, our categorial system lacks an abstract concept to cover these two dimensions.

div.head: vtoS.+yi3+V
div.p: transitive verb with sentential object, this phrase being followed by and in construction with 以／已 followed by a verbal expression

note.p: There are not many words in this category, but one needs to be on the look-out for more instances of this curious construction. The analysis of the context is non-comittal and uninteresting so far. The detailed interpretation of this construction remains an open question. What this entry does is to allow one to collect relevant examples in one place.

div.head: vtpost.vt(oN)
div.p: transitive verb preceded by another transitive verb with an omitted contextually determinate nominal object

note.p: The object of this transitive verb is introduced by another transitive verb, a current phenomenon. Compare vtt+N1.postvt(+N2) 以告 x, where the direct object is also introduced by a subordinate preceding transitive verb.

div.head: npro{OBJ}+Vt.adV
div.p: question object pronoun preceding and in construction with a transitive verb, that phrase preceding and modifying a verbal expression

div.head: vt[0]{NEG}+Vt(oN)
div.p: Negative verb with a lexically determinate omitted subject prededing and in construction with a transitive verbal construction with an omitted and contextually determinate object.

div.head: vt01oN1.postvt02oN2:adS
div.p: subjectless verb with its object coming after another such subjectless verb with its object, this whole phrase modifying a main sentence 自王公逮庶人

div.head: NP[adN.]pr
div.p: Proper name NP preceding and modifying a nominal expression.

div.head: vtpost.npro:+prep+N
div.p: transitive verb preceded by a pronoun, that whole phrase preceding and being in construction with a preposition followed by its nominal object

note.p: This is a way of recording an unusual construction with 自 . It is doubtful that there are many verbs that can function in this way.

div.head: N
div.p: Nominal expression, simplex or complex. Defined as being in principle negatable by 非 .

div.head: vt+.Vt[0]oS
div.p: transitive verb followed by a construction consisting of a transitive verbal expression with its sentential object.

note.p: Surely this must be coordinated with the relevant categories for 問 etc!

div.head: PP+Npr
div.p: Sequence of grammaticalised particles followed by a proper name nominal expression.

div.head: vt(+N1.)adV:postN2
div.p: transitive verb with a contextually determinate nominal object, this phrase preceding and modifying a verbal expression, this whole phrase in turn being in construction with a preceding nominal expression

div.head: nabpost-S1.adS2
div.p: abstract noun in construction with a preceding sentence, that construction preceding and modifying another sentence.

div.head: npost-N1.adN2
div.p: noun being modified by a preceding other nominal expression, that whole phrase preceding yet another nominal expression.

div.head: vtt+prep+N1[.+N2]
div.p: ditransitive verb with its direct object introduced by a preposition, with a lexically determinate generic indirect object.

div.head: PPadV.postS
div.p: a complex particle preceding and modifying a verbal, that whole phrase being in construction with a preceding sentence

div.head: vt[0]postadN[NU]
div.p: transitive verb with lexically determinate subject modifying a preceding number noun

div.head: vpostS
div.p: verb in construction with a preceding sentence.

div.head: VPtpost-.vt+N{OBJ}
div.p: transitive complex verbal expression being preceded and modified by a transitive verb with its nominal object.

div.head: npost.N1+N2
div.p: a noun in construction with a preceding collocation of two nominals

div.head: NP
div.p: composite nominal complex nominal expression.

note.p: Our concept of NP differs, for systematic theoretical reasons, from that current in general linguistics because the concept of a word as distinct from an idiomatic syntactic collocation is not well-defined for classical Chinese.

The question of the wordhood of a given NP does not arise until a testable criterion or definition of the notion of the word for classical Chinese is forthcoming. It is not clear that the notion of a word, as it is currently employed for many languages, usefully applies to an ancient language like classical Chinese where intonational features of wordhood cannot normally be tested.

There are binomes like 葡萄 and 蝴蝶 which are bisyllabic but not semantically compound because their parts have no independent meaning. These belong to the category nn "semantically unanalysable binome", in analogy with the much commoner category series of vv "unanalysable verbal binomes". And any definition of the notion of a word for classical Chinese would have to classify these as words rather than as syntactic compounds, one would have thought.
Reduplicated "NPs" are listed under n.red

div.head: vt(oN1{PIVOT}).+Vt+N2
div.p: transitive verb preceding and in construction with a contextually determinate omitted pivot noun, this whole phrase preceding and being in construction with a verb with its nominal object

note.p: This is a curious marginal category which ultimately has to be explaned morphologically, I suspect. Thus 命曰 will simply become a VPt meaning "call (something) X". The etmology of this kind of construction is at issue in the present tentative categorial analysis.

div.head: vt[+V[0]]
div.p: transitive verb with its lexially determinate verbal object.

div.head: vtoNab{ACT}.-V
div.p: transitive verb followed by a an abstract action-noun, this whole phrase preceding and being modified by a verbal expression

note.p: One might feel that this should be registered simply as vt+N.-V, but one is curious to know how many cases there are where this nominal object is in fact an action nominalisation. Thus this category demonstrates that in our context syntactic categories have no "metaphysical" status as somehow "real" distinct syntactic functions. They are simply convenient labels to make distinct syntactic phenomena systematically retrievable.

div.head: VPpostadV.adN
div.p: complex verbal expression following and modifying a verb, this whole expression preceding and modifying a nominal expression.

div.head: VPt[0](oN)
div.p: complex verbal expression with a lexically determinate obligatorily omitted subject and a contextually determinate object.

div.head: padN.adV
div.p: adnominal particle preceding a (predicative) verbal expression.

div.head: NPab{N1adN2}
div.p: abstract complex nominal expression; construction type: N1 precedes and modifies N2
[THE BRACKET NEEDS TO BE TRANSFERRED TO THE FIELD "CONSTRUCTION TYPE"]

note.p: It is puzzling that so few abstract NPs have been registered so far. One would have thought that this is a very large class. One needs to record more lexicalised cases. Non-lexicalised cases of NPs of this kind are, of course, very easy to find.
For the problematic criteria of lexicalisation see the Grammar.

div.head: nadV{PASS}
div.p: noun preceding and modifying a passive verbal expression.

div.head: vttoN1.+N2
div.p: ditransitive verb followed by its direct object, and this followed by an indirect nominal object

note.p: 1. We need to separate out the cases where the indirect object comes last and subsume them under vtt+N1.oN2, in accordance with our principles on the distinction between "o" and "+".

2. Double object constructions are often notoriously difficult to distinguish reliably from single object constructions with a nominal complement. Time complements are obviously not construed as indirect objects, but place nouns can raise problems with movement verbs.

div.head: p+N.postS
div.p: a particle which precedes and modifies a nominal expression, this whole phrase being in construction with a preceding sentence

note.p: The grammatical relation between 況 and the noun it is in construction with seems puzzling and deserves close discussion. Our notation is non-committal at this stage. Note the contrast with 何況 . There is nothing wrong, it seems to me, with categories that have only one example. The decisive point is that we must know how to look for more examples.

div.head: VPt+N1.postadN2
div.p: complex transitive verb with its object, modifying a preceding nominal expression

div.head: vi0
div.p: an intransitive verb without an explicit or implicit and contextually determinate subject of any kind, definite or indefinite (e.g. yu3 雨 "it is raining")

note.p: Since the judgment that something is vi0 depends on an assessment whether a non-overt subject is or is not to be taken as "understood", there is an uncomfortable subjectivity in the judgment whether something is a subjectless word or not. For practical reasons, it is important to register all plausibe or even possible cases of subjectlessness in order to be prepared for a systematic investigation of the proper boundaries of the phenomenon.

Note that the common absence of an overt subject does not necessarily argue for the subjectlessness of verb. In the case ke3 可 "this is acceptable" the presence of pronominal subject is rare, and ***shi4 ke3 ye3 是可也 "such a thing is acceptable"*** is not a sentence we expect to find very commonly. Nonetheless, there is no sense in which ke3 可 places a feature "acceptability" in some location. On the contrary, it attaches this predicate to a subject. Thus the syntactic diagnose that something is an ordinary vi and not a v0 is in fact partly based on logical and semantic considerations - some might wish to stress "it is based on logical and semantic Western prejudice".

div.head: PPpostS1.adS2
div.p: complex grammaticalised particle phrase following after and in construction with one sentence, and that whole consstruction preceding and modifying another sentence.

div.head: vi.red:-V{SUF}
div.p: reduplicated intransitive verb followed and modified by a verbal suffix

bibl.title: Formations adverbiales a quasi-suffixe en chinois archaique et dans la langue de l'epoque Han.
漢語重言詞詞典 Hanyu chongwenci cidian

div.head: npro(.adV)
div.p: pronoun functioning as an adverb to an omitted verbal expression

div.head: vadV.red
div.p: verb preceding and modifying another verb, reduplicated.

div.head: ppostadS1.adS2
div.p: particle modifying a preceding sentence, this phrase preceding and modifying another sentence

div.head: padS1.+S2
div.p: particle preceding and modifying a sentence, and this construction being followed by and in construction with a second sentence.

div.head: npro.post-N{PRED}
div.p: pronoun modified by a prededing predicative nominal expression

div.head: npro.postVt:adV[0]
div.p: pronoun in construction with a preceding transitive verb, this phrase preceding and modifying a verbal expression with a lexically determinate omitted subject.

div.head: NP[adN.][post=npro_1]
div.p: NP[adN] in apposition with a lexically determinate first person pronoun npro_1.

div.head: vpostadVtoN
div.p: verb modifying a preceding transitive verb with its nominal object

note.p: These adverbs (which one might also conveniently subsume simply under vtpostadV, of which categoy it is a subtype), are all amenable to an analysis where the co-called postposed adverb is taken as a verb with a nominalised verb phrase or sentence as its subject.

div.head: padV.postNPab{S}
div.p: particle preceding and modifying a verbal expression, that phrase being in construction with a preceding nominalised sentence

div.head: NPab{n.red}
div.p: abstract noun; construction type: reduplicated noun
[THE BRACKET NEEDS TO BE TRANSFERRED TO THE FIELD "CONSTRUCTION TYPE"]

note.p: For reduplicated words see WANG WEIMAO 1999.

bibl.title: 漢語重言詞詞典 Hanyu chongwenci cidian

div.head: PPpostNab{NOMINALISED TOPIC}
div.p: particle binome in construction with a preceding abstract topic

note.p: This experimental category is just a reminder of systematic analysis that needs to be done.

div.head: vt0oN{SUBJ}
div.p: subjectless transitive verb followed by a nominal that functions as its subject.

div.head: n.red+V{PRED}
div.p: reduplicated noun (which serves as subject/topic) followed by a verbal expression which functions as predicate

div.head: vtoN1.postadN2
div.p: transitive verb with the nominal object N1, following and modifying the noun N2.

div.head: P
div.p: Grammaticalised particle, simplex or complex. Defined as not constituting a predicate which is open to being negated by either 不 or 非 (except in the trivial case of autonymous use where the particle is used to refer to the particle itself, in which case the particle is used as a nominal expression).

div.head: npro0
div.p: nonreferential pronoun

note.p: The "0" after pronouns refers to non-referential pronouns in the sense that the pronouns in questions do not invite one to identify any item, thing, or person.

div.head: vt[0]+V[0].postV
div.p: transitive verb with a lexically determinate omitted subject preceding and in construction with a verbal expression with an omitted lexically determinate subject. that whole expression preceded by and in construction with a verbal expression.

div.head: vttoN1.+prep+N2:adVtoS
div.p: ditransitive verb followed by a direct object and then an indirect object, this whole phrase preceding and modifying a verbal expression

div.head: vpostS1.adS2
div.p: verb following a sentence, preceding and modifying another sentence

div.head: NPpostVtt.+V[0]
div.p: NP used as a pivot.

note.p: The point of this elusive category is that it allows us to collect those NPs that seem especially disposed to function as pivots. One might well decide, in the end, to do without such a category.

div.head: VPi0postadV
div.p: subjectless complex verb phrase following after and modifying a main verbal expression.

div.head: pad.N+DENG3
div.p: particle preceding and modifying a nominal expression which in turn is followed by and modified by the plural marker 等 .

div.head: vttoN{PIVOT}.+N{PRED}
div.p: pivot construction to be reanalised.

div.head: vt+prep+V
div.p: transitive verb followed by a V preceded by a preposition

div.head: vi2
div.p: intransitive verb with two subjects

note.p: In many cases the distinction with a transitive verb is not clear. For example, in X 與 Y 盟 "X and Y made a contract" there often is no way of making the distinction with "X made a contract with Y". However, since this vt-interpretation is not always possible, we maintain this category.

div.head: npro.red+V
div.p: reduplicated pronoun preceding and in construction with a verbal expression.

div.head: VPt+N.adV
div.p: transitive complex verb followed by its nominal object, this whole phrase preceding and mofifying a main verbal expression.

note.p: This is properly categorised under vt+prep+N.adV.

div.head: VPpostNab{ACT}
div.p: complex verbal expression in construction with a preceding abstract action nominalisation

div.head: NPpro[.adN:]postVt
div.p: complex pronoun preceding and modifying an understood lexically determinate nominal expression, that whole expression serving as the object of a preceding transitive verb.

div.head: nmadN
div.p: mass noun preceding and modifying a main noun

note.p: A great many nadN need to be moved into this category.

div.head: npropost.N+V{PRED}
div.p: pronoun in construction with a preceding subject noun followed by a verbal predicate

div.head: {VPt0...}
div.p: {transitive complex verbal constituent with no logical subject}

div.head: v[adN]
div.p: Exocentric construction consisting of a verb modifying a lexically determinate omitted nominal expression.

div.head: npro.post-N:adS
div.p: pronoun preceded and modified by a (time) nominal, that whole expression preceding and modifying a sentence.

div.head: npost-N.adS
div.p: noun modified by a preceding nominal expression, this phrase preceding and modifying a sentence.

note.p: The counting of such abstract nouns is always by type or kind, never by concrete items, of course, since these nouns do not have concrete referential physical meanings.
Moreover, none of the abstract nouns are counted with classifiers.

div.head: PP
div.p: a combination of more than one particle

note.p: This is a lame and tame preliminary collection of forms. A great deal of work needs to be done on complex particles. In general, grammatical particles are the last elements that are to be entered into the system. The idea is to start out from non-empty words, rather than empty words. Good dictionaries of complex particles exist. However, none of these concentrate on structural analysis.

bibl.title: 文言複式虛詞
古漢語虛詞詞典

div.head: npro.postVt
div.p: verbal, which is a contraction of a transitive verb which follows a transitive verbal as its object

note.p: This category is in a sense "unnatural": in it we record the occurrence of pronouns in object position. And we do this simply in order to chart the different behaviour of different pronouns in this respect. In principle, one could mark all nouns that occur in object versus subject positions, but in general nouns are indifferent to these two functions.

div.head: vtt(oN1).+N2:-V[0]
div.p: ditransitive verb with a contextually determinate indirect object, followed by the direct nominal object, that whole phrase being followed by and modified by a verbal expression.

div.head: NPpro=N
div.p: pronominal followed by a nominal expression in apposition with it.

note.p: We might want to write NPpro.appN

div.head: pad.N-BEI4
div.p: particle preceding and mofifying a nominal expression postmodified by 輩

div.head: n{CLASSIFIER}+N
div.p: classifier noun preceding and in construction with a nominal (indicating the quantity of the latter)

note.p: Since we have defined classifiers as grammaticalised nouns being preceded by a number phrase, when this number phrase is not present, we need to indicate the "classifier nature" of the noun in question by a semantic gloss - thus messily introducing a gloss into our syntactic description. This messiness, on the other hand, is taken to signal something structurally quite special that is going on in the constructions in question.

div.head: v.adVt1+.Vt2+N
div.p: verb modifying a construction consisting of a transitive verb the object of which is another transitive verbal with its object.

div.head: ppostN.+V
div.p: particle in construction with a preceding nominal, this phrase preceding and modifying a verbal

note.p: (It is pleasing to see how the formula, here as often, comes to be much more transparent and easy than its English paraphrase.)

It appears that the predicative use of a construction like 屈產 is uncommon or unidiomatic, to say the least, and therefore I take this word to be subcategorised not only for the post-nominal but also for the adnominal position.

div.head: vt0oN.adV
div.p: subjectless verb with its object, this phrase modifying a verb phrase with an explicit or implicit subject that follows (e.g. zhi4 至 "until" as in 至暮不來 "did not come until the evening" 至秋不成。 "by the autumn they do not ripen".)

note.p: The question whether the V has to be taken as a "minor sentence" often raises a moot point. And as often mentioned elsewhere the minor as well as the major verbal sentence should be taken as a subtype of a V.

The question who arrived at the evening cannot be answered with a plausible classical Chinese word. Clearly, zhi4 至 "until" is derived from the verb "to arrive at". But the point is that this verb is here used in a puzzling subjectless way.
